title: China, U.S. kick off new round of tariffs
text:
The U.S. and China both began imposing additional tariffs on each other's goods Sunday, the latest escalation in a trade war with no end in sight.

But U.S. President Donald Trump said the two sides would still meet for talks later this month.

(SOUND BITE) (ENGLISH) U.S. PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP, SAYING:

"We are talking to China. The meeting is still on. That hasn't changed. They haven't changed and we haven't. We'll see what happens. But we can't allow China to keep ripping us off anymore as a country."

The new round of tariffs took effect Sunday morning, with Beijing's tax of 5% on U.S. crude marking the first time oil has been targeted since the world's two largest economies started their trade war more than a year ago.

The Trump administration began collecting 15% tariffs on more than $125 billion in Chinese imports, including smart speakers, Bluetooth headphones and many types of footwear.

In retaliation, China started to impose additional tariffs on $75 billion worth of U.S. goods.

Chinese state media said on Sunday: "The United States should learn how to behave like a responsible global power and stop acting as a 'school bully.'"

"...it needs to shoulder its due responsibility, and join other countries in making this world a better and more prosperous place. Only then can America become great again."

Trump's aggressive stance has taken a toll across Wall Street in recent weeks, especially on the shares of companies that rely heavily on the Chinese economy.

U.S. investors will be eyeing retail stocks this week to see which companies are weathering the tariffs. But not until Tuesday, as U.S. markets are closed for Labor Day.
